The greatest part of the nation was gradually reduced into a state of servitude3 com- pelled to perpetual labour on the estates of the Gallie nobles, and confined to the soil, either by the real weight of fetters, or by the no less cruel and forcible restraints of the laws. During the long series of troubles which agitated Gaul, from the reign of Gallienus ¹ to that of Diocletian, the condition of these servile peasants was peculiarly miserable3 and they egperienced at once the complicated tyranny of their masters, of the barbarians, of the soldiers‚ and of the officers of the revenue ¹⁹.

Their patience was at last provoked into despair. On every fide they rose in rnuhstudes, armed with rustic weapons, and with ir·- refistilile fury. The ploughman became a foot soldier, the shep- herd mounted on horseback, the deserted villages and open towns were abandoned to the flames, and the ravages of the peasants equalled those of the fiercest barbarians ²⁰. They asserted the natural rights of men, but they asserted those rights with the most savage cruelty. The Gallie nobles justly dreading theirlrevenge, either took refuge in the fortified cities‚ or fled from the wild scene of anarchy. The peasants reigned without control; and two of their most during leaders had the folly and rassmess to assume the Im- perial ornaments ²¹. Their power soon expircd at the approach of the legions.
